ETGL-DDPG: A Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient Algorithm for Sparse Reward Continuous Control

Ehsan Futuhi1, Shayan Karimi1, Chao Gao2, Martin MÃ¼ller1
1Department of Computing Science, University of Alberta
2Huawei Canada Research Center, Edmonton, Canada
Abstract

We consider deep deterministic policy gradient (DDPG) in the context of reinforcement learning with sparse rewards. To enhance exploration, we introduce a search procedure, Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡{\epsilon}{t}italic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy, which generates exploratory options for exploring less-visited states. We prove that search using Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy has polynomial sample complexity under mild MDP assumptions. To more efficiently use the information provided by rewarded transitions, we develop a new dual experience replay buffer framework, GDRB, and implement longest n-step returns. The resulting algorithm, ETGL-DDPG, integrates all three techniques: Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy, GDRB, and Longest nğ‘›nitalic_n-step, into DDPG. We evaluate ETGL-DDPG on standard benchmarks and demonstrate that it outperforms DDPG, as well as other state-of-the-art methods, across all tested sparse-reward continuous environments. Ablation studies further highlight how each strategy individually enhances the performance of DDPG in this setting.

1 Introduction

Deep deterministic policy gradient (DDPG)Â (Lillicrap etÂ al., 2015) is one of the representative algorithms for reinforcement learning (RL)Â (Sutton & Barto, 2018), alongside other prominent approaches (Haarnoja etÂ al., 2018; Fujimoto etÂ al., 2018; Andrychowicz etÂ al., 2017). The method has been extensively used for continuous control environments with dense reward signalsÂ (Duan etÂ al., 2016). However, its performance degrades significantly when the reward signals are sparse and are only observed upon reaching the goalÂ (Matheron etÂ al., 2019).

In sparse-reward environments where success depends on reaching a goal state, DDPGâ€™s deficiency can be explained from three perspectives. The first one is its lack of directional exploration. Like other off-policy RL algorithms, DDPG employs a behavior policy for exploring the environment. The standard choices are either an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-greedy behavior policy that samples a random action with probability Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ (e.g., 0.10.10.10.1), or the main policy with artificial noise. As argued inÂ (Dabney etÂ al., 2020), these one-step noise augmented greedy strategies are ineffective for exploring large sparse-reward state spaces due to the lack of temporal abstraction. To improve Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-greedy, Dabney etÂ al. (2020) propose a temporally extended Ïµâ¢zitalic-Ïµğ‘§\epsilon zitalic_Ïµ italic_z-greedy policy that expands exploration into multiple steps, controlled by a distribution zğ‘§zitalic_z. Ïµâ¢zitalic-Ïµğ‘§\epsilon zitalic_Ïµ italic_z-greedy represents an advancement from the option framework for reinforcement learningÂ (Sutton etÂ al., 1999). Theoretically, an option Oğ‘‚Oitalic_O is defined as a tuple O=âŸ¨I,Ï€,Î²âŸ©ğ‘‚ğ¼ğœ‹ğ›½O=\langle I,\pi,\beta\rangleitalic_O = âŸ¨ italic_I , italic_Ï€ , italic_Î² âŸ©, where Iğ¼Iitalic_I is the set of states where an option can begin, Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ is the option policy that determines which actions to take while executing the option, and Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² is the termination condition. In Ïµâ¢zitalic-Ïµğ‘§\epsilon zitalic_Ïµ italic_z-greedy, each option repeats a primitive action for a specific number of time steps which is sampled from a distribution zğ‘§zitalic_z (e.g., a uniform distribution). The option can begin at any state with probability Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ and terminates whenever their length reaches a limit that is decided by zğ‘§zitalic_z. While Ïµâ¢zitalic-Ïµğ‘§\epsilon zitalic_Ïµ italic_z-greedy improves over Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-greedy, it is also directionless: for exploratory action, the agent does not use any information from its experience for more informed exploration.

The second drawback of DDPG is its uniform treatment of zero and non-zero rewards in the replay buffer. For most off-policy RL algorithms, a replay buffer is used to store and sample transitions of the agentâ€™s interactions with the environment. By default, DDPG uses a uniform sampling strategy that assigns an equal probability of being chosen to all transitions in the buffer. In sparse-reward environments, uniform sampling therefore rarely chooses rewarded transitions. In general, RL algorithms can be improved by prioritizing transitions based on the associated rewards or TD errorÂ (Schaul etÂ al., 2015). For problems with well-defined goals, a replay buffer can be further enhanced to exploit the strong correlation of rewards and goals. The third weakness of DDPG is its slow information propagation when updating its learning policy. Since only the last transition in a successful episode (i.e., goal reached) gets rewarded, in standard DDPG, the agent must achieve the goal many times to make sure that the reward is eventually propagated backward to early states. It is known that one way to achieve this is to provide intermediate rewards with reward shaping methodsÂ (Laud, 2004). However, effective reward shaping is usually problem-specific and does not generalize to a wide range of tasks.

In this paper, we enhance DDPGÂ (Lillicrap etÂ al., 2015) to address all three aforementioned problems. Our first contribution is Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy, a new temporally version of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-greedy that utilizes a light-weight search procedure, similar to Laud (2004), to enable more directional exploration based on the agentâ€™s previous experience data. We show that similar to Ïµâ¢zitalic-Ïµğ‘§\epsilon zitalic_Ïµ italic_z-greedy, Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy has polynomial sample complexity in related parameters of the MDP. Our second contribution is a new goal-conditioned dual replay buffer (GDRB), that uses two replay buffers along with an adaptive sampling strategy to differentiate goal-reached and goal-not-reached experience data. These two buffers differ in retention policy, size, and the transitions they store. Our third enhancement is to replace the one-step update in DDPG with the longest nğ‘›nitalic_n-step return for all transitions in an episode. FigureÂ 1 illustrates the innovations of ETGL-DDPG. In Section 4, we evaluate the performance of ETGL-DDPG through extensive experiments on 2D and 3D continuous control benchmarks. We show that each of the three strategies individually improves the performance of DDPG. Furthermore, ETGL-DDPG outperforms current state-of-the-art methods across all tested environments.

2.2 Locality-Sensitive Hashing

Our approach discretizes the state space with a hash function Ï•:ğ•Šâ†’ğ•„:italic-Ï•â†’ğ•Šğ•„\phi:\mathbb{S}\rightarrow\mathbb{M}italic_Ï• : blackboard_S â†’ blackboard_M, that maps states to buckets in ğ•„ğ•„\mathbb{M}blackboard_M. When we encounter a state sğ‘ sitalic_s, we increment the visit count for Ï•â¢(s)italic-Ï•ğ‘ \phi(s)italic_Ï• ( italic_s ). We use nâ¢(Ï•â¢(s))ğ‘›italic-Ï•ğ‘ n(\phi(s))italic_n ( italic_Ï• ( italic_s ) ) as the visit counts of all states that map to the same bucket Ï•â¢(s)italic-Ï•ğ‘ \phi(s)italic_Ï• ( italic_s ). Clearly, the granularity of the discretization significantly impacts our exploration method. The goal for the granularity is that â€œdistantâ€ states are in separate buckets while â€œsimilarâ€ states are grouped into one.

We use Locality-Sensitive Hashing (LSH) as our hashing function, a popular class of hash functions for querying nearest neighbors based on a similarity metric (Bloom, 1970). SimHashÂ (Charikar, 2002) is a computationally efficient LSH method that calculates similarity based on angular distance. SimHash retrieves a binary code of state sâˆˆSğ‘ ğ‘†s\in Sitalic_s âˆˆ italic_S as

Ï•â¢(s)=sâ¢gâ¢nâ¢(Aâ¢fâ¢(s))âˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}k,italic-Ï•ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘”ğ‘›ğ´ğ‘“ğ‘ superscript11ğ‘˜\phi(s)=sgn(Af(s))\in\{-1,1\}^{k},italic_Ï• ( italic_s ) = italic_s italic_g italic_n ( italic_A italic_f ( italic_s ) ) âˆˆ { - 1 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (2)

where f:Sâ†’â„D:ğ‘“â†’ğ‘†superscriptâ„ğ·f:S\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{D}italic_f : italic_S â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a preprocessing function and Ağ´Aitalic_A is a kÃ—Dğ‘˜ğ·k\times Ditalic_k Ã— italic_D matrix with i.i.d. entries drawn from a standard Gaussian distribution ğ’©â¢(0,1)ğ’©01\mathcal{N}(0,1)caligraphic_N ( 0 , 1 ). The parameter kğ‘˜kitalic_k determines the granularity of the hash: larger values result in fewer collisions, thereby enhancing the ability to distinguish between different states.

3 The ETGL-DDPG Method

In this section, we describe three strategies in ETGL-DDPG for improving DDPG in sparse-reward tasks. The full pseudocode for ETGL-DDPG is presented in Supplementary Algorithm 3.

3.1 Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-Greedy: Exploration with search

In principle, exploration should be highest at the beginning of training, as discovering rewarded transitions during early steps is essential for escaping local optimaÂ (Matheron etÂ al., 2019). Motivated by the success of the fast exploration algorithms RRT (LaValle, 1998) and Ïµâ¢zitalic-Ïµğ‘§\epsilon zitalic_Ïµ italic_z-greedyÂ (Dabney etÂ al., 2020), we introduce Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy, which combines Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-greedy with a tree search procedure. Like Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-greedy, Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy selects a greedy action with probability 1âˆ’Ïµ1italic-Ïµ1-\epsilon1 - italic_Ïµ, and an exploratory action with probability Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ. However, instead of exploring uniformly at random, the exploratory action in Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy is the first step of an option generated via a search with time budget Nğ‘Nitalic_N.

To execute the search process, the agent requires access to the environmentâ€™s transition function ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T of the corresponding MDP. This is used to generate new nodes within the search tree. However, since our exploration strategy is built on DDPG, the model-free algorithm, the transition function ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T is not known. Instead, the agent utilizes its replay buffer to advance the search. We briefly discuss the impact of having access to ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T on the exploration process in Supplementary Material A.2. We also assume that the agent has a SimHash function Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•, which discretizes the large continuous environment. For each state sğ‘ sitalic_s, nâ¢(Ï•â¢(s))ğ‘›italic-Ï•ğ‘ n(\phi(s))italic_n ( italic_Ï• ( italic_s ) ) serves as an estimate of the number of visits to a neighbourhood of sğ‘ sitalic_s throughout the entire learning process.

The replay buffer contains transitions observed during training. It can be used as a transition model for observed transitions and an approximate one for transitions similar to those already seen. For simplicity, we identify each bucket with its hash code Ï•â¢(s)italic-Ï•ğ‘ \phi(s)italic_Ï• ( italic_s ). We use a buffer BMsubscriptğµğ‘€B_{M}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which stores observed transitions based on the hash of their states Ï•â¢(s)italic-Ï•ğ‘ \phi(s)italic_Ï• ( italic_s ). If the agent makes a transition (st,at,rt,st+1)subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡1(s_{t},a_{t},r_{t},s_{t+1})( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in the environment, the transition is stored in bucket b=Ï•â¢(st)ğ‘italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡b=\phi(s_{t})italic_b = italic_Ï• ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). All transitions are assigned to their buckets upon being added to the replay buffer. As training may take a long time, we limit the number of transitions in each bucket, and randomly replace one of the old transitions in a full bucket with the new transition.

The function next_state_from_replay_buffer in Algorithm 1 shows how new nodes can be added to the search: assuming we are at node sxsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¥s_{x}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we randomly select a transition (sâ€²,a,r,s)â€²â€²(s^{\prime},a,r,s{{}^{\prime\prime}})( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a , italic_r , italic_s start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT ) in bucket Ï•â¢(sx)italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¥\phi(s_{x})italic_Ï• ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and create a new child sxâ€²s_{x{\prime}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x â€² end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for sxsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¥s_{x}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by using following approximation:

ğ’¯â¢(sx,a)â‰ˆğ’¯â¢(sâ€²,a)ğ’¯subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ’¯superscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘\mathcal{T}(s_{x},a)\approx\mathcal{T}(s^{\prime},a)caligraphic_T ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a ) â‰ˆ caligraphic_T ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a ) (3)

Algorithm 1 explains how the search generates an exploratory option. Initially, at state sğ‘ sitalic_s, we create a list of frontier nodes consisting of only the root node sğ‘ sitalic_s. To justify this exploration method, we adopt the conditions outlined in Liu & Brunskill (2018) to validate the sample efficiency of Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy. We begin by introducing the relevant terms and then present the main theorem. Detailed definitions and proofs are provided in Appendix A.1. The key idea is to define a measure that captures the concept of visiting all state-action pairs, as outlined in Definition 1.

Definition 1 (Covering Length).

The covering length (Even-Dar & Mansour, 2004) represents the minimum number of steps an agent must take in an MDP, starting from any state-action pair (s,a)âˆˆğ’®Ã—ğ’œğ‘ ğ‘ğ’®ğ’œ(s,a)\in\mathcal{S}\times\mathcal{A}( italic_s , italic_a ) âˆˆ caligraphic_S Ã— caligraphic_A, to visit all state-action pairs at least once with a probability of at least 0.5.

Our objective is to find a near-optimal policy, as defined in Definition 2.

Definition 2 (Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-optimal Policy).

3.2 GDRB: Goal-conditioned Dual Replay Buffer

The experience replay buffer is an indispensable part of deep off-policy RL algorithms. It is common to use only one buffer to store all transitions and use FIFO as the retention policy, with the most recent data replacing the oldest dataÂ (Mnih etÂ al., 2013). As an alternative, in the reservoir sampling (Vitter, 1985) retention policy, each transition in the buffer has an equal chance of being overwritten. This maintains coverage of some older data over training. RS-DRB (Zhang etÂ al., 2019) uses two replay buffers, one for exploitation and the other for exploration. The transitions made by the agentâ€™s policy are stored in the exploitation buffer, and the random exploratory transitions are stored in the exploration buffer. For the retention policy, the exploration buffer uses reservoir sampling, while the exploitation buffer uses FIFO.

Inspired by this dual replay buffer framework, we propose a Goal-conditioned Double Replay Buffer (GDRB). The first buffer DÎ²subscriptğ·ğ›½D_{\beta}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUBSCRIPT stores all transitions during training, and the second buffer Desubscriptğ·ğ‘’D_{e}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT stores the transitions that belong to successful episodes (i.e., goal reached). DÎ²subscriptğ·ğ›½D_{\beta}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uses reservoir sampling, and Desubscriptğ·ğ‘’D_{e}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uses FIFO. Since DÎ²subscriptğ·ğ›½D_{\beta}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUBSCRIPT needs to cover transitions from the entire training process, it is larger than Desubscriptğ·ğ‘’D_{e}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We balance the number of samples taken from the two buffers with an adaptive sampling ratio. Specifically, in a training process of Eğ¸Eitalic_E episodes, at current episode iğ‘–iitalic_i, the sampling ratios Ï„esubscriptğœğ‘’\tau_{e}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ï„Î²subscriptğœğ›½\tau_{\beta}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for Desubscriptğ·ğ‘’D_{e}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and DÎ²subscriptğ·ğ›½D_{\beta}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are set as follows: Ï„e=iE,Ï„Î²=1âˆ’Ï„e.formulae-sequencesubscriptğœğ‘’ğ‘–ğ¸subscriptğœğ›½1subscriptğœğ‘’\tau_{e}=\frac{i}{E},\tau_{\beta}=1-\tau_{e}.italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_i end_ARG start_ARG italic_E end_ARG , italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 - italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . To select Cğ¶Citalic_C mini-batches, maxâ¡(âŒŠÏ„Î²âˆ—CâŒ‹,1)subscriptğœğ›½ğ¶1\max(\left\lfloor\tau_{\beta}*C\right\rfloor,1)roman_max ( âŒŠ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— italic_C âŒ‹ , 1 ) mini-batches are chosen from DÎ²subscriptğ·ğ›½D_{\beta}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the rest from Desubscriptğ·ğ‘’D_{e}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Later stages of training still sample from DÎ²subscriptğ·ğ›½D_{\beta}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to not forget previously acquired knowledge, as we assume the policy is more likely to reach the goal as the training progresses. In case that Desubscriptğ·ğ‘’D_{e}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is empty, since there are no successful episodes yet, we draw all mini-batches from DÎ²subscriptğ·ğ›½D_{\beta}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

3.3 Using Longest nğ‘›nitalic_n-step return

In standard DDPG, Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q-values are updated using one-step TD. In goal-reaching tasks with sparse rewards, only one rewarded transition per successful episode is added to the replay buffer. The agent needs rewards provided by these transitions to update its policy toward reaching the goal. With few rewarded transitions, the agent should exploit a successful path to the goal many times so the reward is propagated backward quickly. Multi-step updates can accelerate this process by looking ahead several steps, resulting in more rewarded transitions in the replay bufferÂ (Meng etÂ al., 2021; Hessel etÂ al., 2018). For example, Meng etÂ al. (2021) utilize nğ‘›nitalic_n-step updates in DDPG with nğ‘›nitalic_n ranging from 1111 to 8888. In our design, to share the reward from the last step of a successful episode for all transitions in the episode, we use longest nğ‘›nitalic_n-step return (Mnih etÂ al., 2016), shown in Equation 6.

Qâ¢(st,at)={âˆ‘k=0Tâˆ’tÎ³kâ¢rt+k,sTÂ is a goal stateâˆ‘k=0Tâˆ’tâˆ’1Î³kâ¢rt+k+Î³Tâˆ’tâ¢Qâ¢(sT,aT),otherwiseğ‘„subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡casessubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘¡ğ‘˜0superscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘˜sTÂ is a goal stateotherwiseotherwiseotherwisesubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘¡1ğ‘˜0superscriptğ›¾ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptğ›¾ğ‘‡ğ‘¡ğ‘„subscriptğ‘ ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘ğ‘‡otherwiseotherwiseQ(s_{t},a_{t})=\begin{cases}\sum^{T-t}_{k=0}\gamma^{k}r_{t+k},\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ % \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \text{$s_{T}$ is a goal % state}\\ \\ \sum^{T-t-1}_{k=0}\gamma^{k}r_{t+k}+\gamma^{T-t}Q(s_{T},a_{T}),\ \ \ \ \ \text% {otherwise}\end{cases}italic_Q ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a goal state end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , otherwise end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW (6)

Here, sTsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘‡s_{T}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the last state in the episode. Using the longest n-step return for each transition from a successful episode, the reward is immediately propagated to all Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q-value updates. In unsuccessful episodes, using the longest nğ‘›nitalic_n-step return reduces the overestimation bias in Q-valuesÂ (Thrun & Schwartz, 1993). Meng etÂ al. (2021) empirically show that using multi-step updates can improve the performance of DDPG on robotic tasks mostly by reducing overestimation bias â€” they demonstrate that the larger the number of steps, the lower the estimated target Q-value and overestimation bias.

4 experiments

In this section, we show the details of how ETGL-DDPG improves DDPG for sparse-reward tasks using its three strategies. We use experiments to answer the following questions: 1) Can ETGL-DDPG outperform state-of-the-art methods in goal-reaching tasks with sparse rewards? 2) How does each of these three innovations impact the performance of DDPG? 3) Can Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy explore more efficiently than Ïµâ¢zitalic-Ïµğ‘§\epsilon zitalic_Ïµ italic_z-greedy and other common exploration strategies?

We consider two types of tasks: navigation and manipulation. We use three sparse-reward continuous environments for navigation. The first environment is a 2D maze called Wall-maze (Trott etÂ al., 2019), where a reward of -1 is given at each step, and a reward of 10 is given if the goal is reached. The start and goal states for each episode are randomly selected from the blue and green regions, respectively, as shown in Figure 2a. The agentâ€™s action (dx,dy) determines the amount of movement along both axes. The environment contains a gradient cliff feature (Lehman etÂ al., 2018), where the fastest way to reach the goal results in a deadlock close to the goal. Our second and third 3D environments are U-maze (Figure 2b) and Point-push (Figure 2c) (Kanagawa, 2021), designed using the MuJoCo physics engine (Todorov etÂ al., 2012). In both environments, a robot (orange ball) seeks to reach the goal (red region). In Point-push, the robot must additionally push aside the two movable red blocks that obstruct the path to the goal. A small negative reward of -0.001 is given at each step unless the goal is reached, where the reward is 1. In each episode, the robot starts near the same position with slight random variations, but the goal region remains fixed.

We also employ three manipulation tasks: window-open, soccer, and button-press (Figures 2d, e, and f) (Yu etÂ al., 2020). In window-open, the goal is to push the window open; in soccer, the goal is to kick the ball into the goal; and in button-press, the aim is to press the top-down button. Each episode begins with the robotâ€™s gripper in a randomized starting position, while the positions of other objects remain constant. The original versions of these tasks employ a uniquely shaped reward function for each task. However, these versions offer limited challenges for exploration, as standard baselines, such as SAC, demonstrate strong performanceÂ (Yu etÂ al., 2020). We modified the original reward function to be sparse, transforming these tasks into challenging exploration problems.

The maximum number of steps per episode is set to 100 for Wall-maze and 500 for all other environments. Across all methods, the neural network architecture consists of 3 hidden layers with 128 units each, using ReLU activation functions. For standard baselines, we utilize the implementations from OpenAI Gym (Dhariwal etÂ al., 2017), and for other baselines, we rely on their publicly available implementations. After testing various configurations, we found that Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy and Ïµâ¢zitalic-Ïµğ‘§\epsilon zitalic_Ïµ italic_z-greedy perform best with budgets of N=40ğ‘40N=40italic_N = 40 and N=15ğ‘15N=15italic_N = 15, respectively, across these environments. Additional details about the environments and experimental setup are provided in Appendix A.3.

4.1 Overall Performance of ETGL-DDPG

We evaluate the performance of ETGL-DDPG compared to state-of-the-art methods. We compare with SAC (Haarnoja etÂ al., 2018), TD3Â (Fujimoto etÂ al., 2018), DDPG, and DOIEÂ (Lobel etÂ al., 2022). DOIE demonstrates state-of-the-art performance in challenging sparse-reward continuous control problems by drastically improving the exploration. While both DOIE and Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy use a similarity measure between new and observed states, DOIE applies this to compute an optimistic value function rather than solely guiding the agent to unexplored areas. The results are shown in Figure 3. In the navigation environments, ETGL-DDPG and DOIE demonstrate superior performance compared to other methods, with ETGL-DDPG achieving a success rate of 1 faster than DOIE. Notably, Wall-maze presents a more challenging task among navigation environments, where only ETGL-DDPG and DOIE are able to achieve a success rate above zero. In manipulation tasks, the press-button poses the hardest challenge as none of the methods achieve a success rate of 1. ETGL-DDPG still outperforms all other approaches, while DOIE underperforms compared to SAC, indicating its limitations in adapting to high dimensional environments.

4.2 Environment Coverage through Exploration

We now examine how effective Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy is in covering the environment. To do so, we discretize the navigation environments into small cells. A cell is considered visited if the agent encounters a sufficient number of distinct states within it, and the overall environment coverage is quantified as the fraction of visited cells. Figure 4 presents a comparison of environment coverage across different exploration strategies. All strategies except DOIE, which uses Radial Basis Function Deep Q-Network (RBFDQN)Â (Asadi etÂ al., 2021), use DDPG as their underlying algorithm. RBFDQN is an enhanced DQN variant that incorporates Radial Basis Functions (RBF) to achieve more accurate Q-value approximations in continuous environments. In Wall-maze, Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy is the only method capable of fully covering the environment, while DOIE achieves 90% coverage. Ïµâ¢zitalic-Ïµğ‘§\epsilon zitalic_Ïµ italic_z-greedy covers approximately half of the environment, whereas the remaining methods manage to explore only around 30%. In U-maze, all strategies are successful, covering 80% or more of the environment. Even so, both Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy and DOIE reach full coverage faster than other methods. In Point-push, none of the methods can fully cover the environment. However, Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy still outperforms all baselines, and among the baselines, DOIE explores more than the others. We also investigate the distribution of final states reached in the episodes to determine the order in which the agent visits different regions of the environment (see Appendix A.5).

The tree budget Nğ‘Nitalic_N upper bounds the option length of Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy due to the fact that the longest path between nodes in the tree is shorter or equal to the number of nodes in the tree. This is analogous to the role of Nğ‘Nitalic_N in Ïµâ¢zitalic-Ïµğ‘§\epsilon zitalic_Ïµ italic_z-greedy, where a uniform distribution zâ¢(n)=ğŸ™nâ‰¤N/Nğ‘§ğ‘›subscript1ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘z(n)=\mathbbm{1}_{n\leq N}/Nitalic_z ( italic_n ) = blackboard_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n â‰¤ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_N is used. To evaluate both methods, we assess environment coverage under varying budget sizes, calculating the coverage after 1 million training frames. Table 1 shows the results: Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy consistently achieves greater coverage than Ïµâ¢zitalic-Ïµğ‘§\epsilon zitalic_Ïµ italic_z-greedy across all environments and budget sizes. Additionally, Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy demonstrates improved the coverage as the budget increases. In contrast, increasing the budget for Ïµâ¢zitalic-Ïµğ‘§\epsilon zitalic_Ïµ italic_z-greedy does not consistently improve coverage and can even decrease it in some cases. This highlights the advantages of directed exploration over undirected methods, particularly in complex environments with numerous obstacles, such as Wall-maze.

4.3 Effectiveness of Each New Component in ETGL-DDPG

We evaluated the performance of ETGL-DDPG, and now we assess the impact of each component on DDPG separately. Figure 5 presents the results for all environments. Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy demonstrates the most improvement across all environments and is the only method that enhances the performance of DDPG in the Wall-maze, highlighting the critical role of our exploration strategy. GDRB shows a positive impact on DDPG performance in all environments, except for soccer, where DDPG alone outperforms all baselines. Additionally, we replaced reservoir sampling with FIFO as the retention policy in GDRB and observed similar results. The longest n-step return has a positive effect only in U-maze and press-button tasks, while it negatively impacts performance in soccer and Point-push. We attribute this to the inherently high variance of multi-step updates. A comparison of Figures 3 and 5 across all environments shows that ETGL-DDPG consistently outperforms the use of each component individually, supporting the effectiveness of their combination.

5 Related work

Exploration. Intrinsic motivation methods Â (Burda etÂ al., 2018; Pathak etÂ al., 2017; Ostrovski etÂ al., 2017; Tang etÂ al., 2017) provide a reward bonus for unexplored areas of the state space. These methods make the reward function non-stationary, which breaks the Markov assumption of MDP. Decoupled RL algorithms (SchÃ¤fer etÂ al., 2021; Badia etÂ al., 2019) resolve the non-stationarity of the reward function by training two separate policies for exploration and exploitation. However, such methods require double the computation cost. Colas etÂ al. (2018) use a policy search process to generate diverse data for training of DDPG. Liu etÂ al. (2018) introduce a competition-based exploration method where two agents (A and B) compete with each other. Agent A is penalized for visiting states visited by B, while B is rewarded for visiting states discovered by A. Plappert etÂ al. (2018) directly inject noise into the policyâ€™s parameter space instead of the action space. Eysenbach etÂ al. (2019) build a graph using states in the replay buffer, allowing the agent to navigate distant regions of the environment by applying Dijkstraâ€™s algorithm. Lobel etÂ al. (2022) present Deep Optimistic Initialization for Exploration (DOIE), which improves exploration in continuous control tasks by maintaining optimism in state-action value estimates. Lobel etÂ al. (2023) demonstrate that DOIE can estimate visit counts by averaging samples from the Rademacher distribution instead of using density models. Dey etÂ al. (2024) present COIN, a continual optimistic initialization strategy that extends DOIE to stochastic and non-stationary environments.

Experience Replay Buffer and Reward Propagation. Rather than uniformly sampling from the buffer, Prioritized Experience Replay (PER) (Schaul etÂ al., 2015) prioritizes transitions in the buffer based on reward, recency, or TD error at the expense of Oâ¢(logâ¡N)ğ‘‚ğ‘O(\log N)italic_O ( roman_log italic_N ) per sample, where Nğ‘Nitalic_N is the buffer size. CERÂ (Zhang & Sutton, 2017) includes the last transition from the buffer to each sampled batch with Oâ¢(1)ğ‘‚1O(1)italic_O ( 1 ) complexity.Â Zhang etÂ al. (2022) learn a conservative value regularizer only from the observed transitions in the replay buffer to improve the sample efficiency of DQN. Pan etÂ al. (2022) theoretically show why PER has a better convergence rate than uniform sampling policy when minimizing mean squared error. Furthermore, Pan etÂ al. (2022) identify two limitations of PER: outdated priorities and insufficient coverage of the state space. Reward shapingÂ (Laud, 2004; Hu etÂ al., 2020) creates artificial intermediate rewards to facilitate reward propagation. However, designing appropriate intermediate rewards is hard and often problem-specific. Trott etÂ al. (2019) address this issue by introducing Â self-balancing reward shaping in the context of on-policy learning. To extract more information from an unsuccessful episode, Andrychowicz etÂ al. (2017) introduce imaginary goals. An imaginary goal for state sğ‘ sitalic_s is a state that is encountered later in the episode. Devidze etÂ al. (2024) introduce a novel reward informativeness criterion that adaptively designs interpretable reward functions based on an agentâ€™s current policy in sparse-reward tasks.

6 Conclusions and Future Work

We have introduced the ETGL-DDPG algorithm with three components that improve the performance of DDPG for sparse-reward goal-conditioned environments. Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy is a temporally-extended version of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-greedy using options generated by search. We prove that Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy achieves a polynomial sample complexity under specific MDP structural assumptions. GDRB employs an extra buffer to separate successful episodes. The longest nğ‘›nitalic_n-step return bootstraps from the Q-value of the final state in unsuccessful episodes and becomes a Monte Carlo update in successful episodes. ETGL-DDPG uses these components with DDPG and outperforms state-of-the-art methods, at the expense of about 1.5x wall-clock time w.r.t DDPG. The current limitation of our work is that we approximate visit counts through static hashing. For image-based problems such as real-world navigation, the future direction is to leverage dynamic hashing techniques such as normalizing flowsÂ (Papamakarios etÂ al., 2021) as these tasks demand more intricate representation learning.

Proof Overview.

We aim to show that the Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy algorithm falls into the PAC-MDP category. A.2 Exploration with a perfect model

Since the DDPG algorithm is model-free, we utilize the replay buffer to construct the tree for Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy. However, Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy can also take advantage of a perfect model when available. The pseudocode for option generation using a perfect model is provided in Algorithm 2. The key difference from Algorithm 1 is the use of the next_state_from_env function instead of next_state_from_replay_buffer to generate child nodes. In this case, an action is uniformly sampled from the action space, and the environmentâ€™s transition function ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T is directly used to determine the next state (line 25). Figure 6 compares the performance of ETGL-DDPG in navigation environments using a perfect model versus a replay buffer. The results show a clear advantage when using a perfect model, as the agent reaches a success rate of 1 more quickly and with less deviation.

A.3 Implementation Details and Experimental Hyperparameters

Here, we describe the implementation details and hyperparameters for all methods used in this paper. All experiments were run on a system with 5 vCPU on a cluster of Intel Xeon E5-2650 v4 2.2GHz CPUs and one 2080Ti GPU. TableÂ 3 displays the details for environments. Tables 2, 4, and 5 showcase the hyperparameters utilized in ETGL-DDPG and the baselines.

A.4 ETGL-DDPG Algorithm

In this section, we introduce ETGL-DDPG, as detailed in Algorithm 3, which is organized into three primary functions: train, run_episode, and update. The train function is called once at the start of the training process. For each training episode, the run_episode function is invoked to perform a training episode within the environment, followed by the update function to adjust the networks based on the experience gained from the episode.

A.5 Terminal states distribution

We analyze the order in which the agent visits different parts of the environment by examining the distribution of the last states in the episodes. To make it more visually appealing and easy to interpret, we only sample some of the episodes. The results for Wall-maze, U-maze, and Point-push can be found in Figures 7, 8, and 9, respectively. In Wall-maze, only Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy and DOIE can effectively navigate to different regions of the environment and ultimately reach the goal area. Other methods often get trapped in one of the local optima and are unable to reach the goal. The reason some methods, such as TD3, have fewer points is that the agent spends a lot of time revisiting congested areas instead of exploring new ones. In U-maze, most methods can explore the majority of the environment. However, during the final stages of training, methods such as DDPG, SAC, and DDPG + intrinsic motivation have lower success rates and may end up in locations other than the goal areas. In Point-push, Ïµâ¢titalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon titalic_Ïµ italic_t-greedy, Ïµâ¢zitalic-Ïµğ‘§\epsilon zitalic_Ïµ italic_z-greedy, and DOIE first visit the lower section of the environment in the early stages. After that, they push aside the movable box and proceed to the upper section to visit the goal area. For the other methods, the pattern is almost the same, with occasional visits to the lower section.
